{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> |name = Darius Rucker |image = Darius Rucker.jpg |caption = Darius Rucker in 2004 at Yokota Air Base, Japan |image_size = 200 |background = solo_singer |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|5|13}} |origin = [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]], [[South Carolina]], U.S. |instrument = [[Vocals]], [[rhythm guitar]] |genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[R&B]], [[Country music|country]] |occupation = [[Singer-songwriter]] |years_active = 1986âpresent |label = [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], [[Hidden Beach Recordings|Hidden Beach]], [[Capitol Nashville]] |associated_acts = [[Hootie & the Blowfish]], [[Frank Rogers (record producer)|Frank Rogers]] |website = }} '''Darius Rucker''' (born May 13, 1966) is an [[United States|American]] musician. He first gained fame as the [[lead singer]] and [[rhythm guitar]]ist of the [[rock music|rock]] band [[Hootie & the Blowfish]], which he founded in 1986 at the [[University of South Carolina]] along with [[Mark Bryan]], [[Jim Sonefeld|Jim "Soni" Sonefeld]] and Dean Felber. The band has released five studio albums with him as a member, and charted six top 40 hits on the [[Billboard Hot 100]]. Rucker co-wrote the majority of the band's songs with the other three members.
He released a solo [[R&B]] album, ''[[Back to Then]]'', in 2002 on [[Hidden Beach Recordings]] but did not chart any singles from it. Six years later, Rucker signed to [[Capitol Records]] Nashville as a [[country music]] artist, releasing the album ''[[Learn to Live]]'' that year. Its first single, "[[Don't Think I Don't Think About It]]", made him the first African American to chart a number one on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts since [[Charley Pride]] in 1983. It was followed by two more number-one singles, "[[It Won't Be Like This for Long]]" and "[[Alright (Darius Rucker song)|Alright]]" and the number three "[[History in the Making]]". In 2009, he became the first African American to win the New Artist Award from the [[Country Music Association]], and only the second African American to win any award from the association. A second Capitol album, ''[[Charleston, SC 1966]]'', was released on October 12, 2010. The album includes the number-one singles "[[Come Back Song]]" and "[[This (Darius Rucker song)|This]]".
==Early life== Darius Rucker was born and raised in Charleston, South Carolina, where his family history goes back generations.<ref name=Puterbaugh>Puterbaugh, Parke (June 15, 1995), "Fish out of water". ''Rolling Stone''. (710):74</ref> His single mother, Carolyn, who was a nurse, raised him with his five siblings: three sisters and two brothers.<ref name=Gray>Gray, Kevin; Dampier, Cindy (April 10, 1995), "Fish out of water". ''People''. '''43''' (14):77</ref> According to Rucker, his father was "never around," and Rucker only saw him before church on Sundays.<ref name=farley>Farley, Christopher Joh; Thigpen, David E.. (April 29, 1996), "Can 13 million Hootie fans really be wrong?" Time, Vol. 147 Issue 18, p74</ref> His father was in a gospel band called The Rolling Stones.<ref name=farley/> Rucker has said that he had a "typical Southern, African-American upbringing."<ref name=Puterbaugh/> His family attended church every Sunday and was economically poor, and at one point, his mother, her two sisters, his grandmother and 14 children were all living in a three-bedroom home.<ref name=Puterbaugh/> Even so, he says that he looks back on his childhood "with very fond memories."<ref name=Puterbaugh/> His sister, L'Corine, recalled that singing "was always his dream".<ref name=Puterbaugh/>
==Hootie & the Blowfish== Rucker has been the lead singer of [[Hootie & the Blowfish]] since its formation in 1986. He met fellow band members, [[Mark Bryan]], Jim "Soni" Sonefeld, and Dean Felber, while attending the [[University of South Carolina]]. Bryan heard Rucker singing in the shower, and the two became a duo, playing [[R.E.M.]] covers at a local venue.<ref name=Kennedy/> They later recruited Felber and finally Sonefeld joined in 1989.<ref name=Kennedy/> As a member of Hootie & the Blowfish, Rucker has recorded five studio albums: ''[[Cracked Rear View]]'', ''[[Fairweather Johnson]]'', ''[[Musical Chairs (Hootie & the Blowfish album)|Musical Chairs]]'', ''[[Hootie & the Blowfish (album)|Hootie & the Blowfish]]'' and ''[[Looking for Lucky]]'', also charting within the top 40 of the [[Billboard Hot 100]] six times.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=hootie-the-blowfish-p44727/charts-awards/billboard-singles|pure_url=yes}}|title=Hootie & the Blowfish chart history|work=Allmusic|accessdate=22 November 2010}}</ref> All six albums feature songs that Rucker, Bryan and Felber wrote. As the frontman, Rucker began to be called simply "Hootie" in the media, though the band title combines the nicknames of his college friends.<ref name=Gray/><ref name=cohen>Cohen, Rich (August 10, 1995), "Southern comfort". ''Rolling Stone'' (714):42</ref>
Rucker's signature contribution to the band is his baritone voice which ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' has called "ingratiating,"<ref>DeCurtis, Anthony; Wild, David (May 13, 1999), "Rock + roll". ''Rolling Stone'' (812):60</ref> ''[[TIME]]'' has called "low, gruff, [and] charismatic,"<ref name=farley/> and ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' has characterized as a "barrelhouse growl."<ref name=browne>Browne, David (April 26, 96), "`Fairweather' report". ''Entertainment Weekly'' (324):55</ref> He has brought additional attention as the sole African-American member of a major rock band with otherwise white members. Rucker said they "flipped" the formula of the all black band with a white frontman, like [[Frank Sinatra]] performing with [[Count Basie]].<ref name=cohen/> Musically, he has sometimes been criticized or spoofed for not being "black enough".<ref name=Kennedy/> ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' ran a sketch of Rucker leading beer-drinking, white [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]] members in a counter-march to [[Louis Farrakhan]]'s [[Million Man March]].<ref name=farley/><ref name=Balwin>Baldwin, Kristen (November 3, 1995), "The week". ''Entertainment Weekly''. (299):54</ref> He also received death threats for singing the Hootie song "Drowning," a protest song against the flying of the [[Confederate flag]] above the South Carolina statehouse.<ref name=farley/> The other band members were protective of Rucker in regards to the issue, and had a policy of generally ignoring racist comments.<ref name=Kennedy>Kennedy, Dana; Estrine, Darryl (July 28, 1995), "Hootie's revenge". ''Entertainment Weekly'' (285):32</ref>
Shortly after gaining a measure of fame, Felber and Rucker (who consider themselves best friends) moved into an apartment in [[Columbia, South Carolina]].<ref name=Kennedy/> With Rucker's recognition as the frontman of a successful band came increased opportunities. In October 1995, Rucker was asked to sing the national anthem at the [[World Series]].<ref name=Balwin/> Frank Sinatra invited Rucker to sing at his 80th birthday party; Rucker sang "[[The Lady Is a Tramp]]."<ref>Russell, Lisa; Ramsay, Carolyn (December 4, 1995), "Frankly admiring".. ''People''. '''44''' (23):85</ref> That same week, he made a voice cameo in an episode of the sitcom ''[[Friends (TV series)|Friends]]''.<ref name=Balwin/> He also joined [[Nanci Griffith]] on the song "Gulf Coast Highway" from her 1997 album ''[[Blue Roses from the Moons]]'',<ref>Stambler, Lyndon (June 2, 1997), "Blue Roses from the Moons". ''People''., '''47''' (21):32</ref> and sang backing vocals on [[Radney Foster]]'s 1999 album ''[[See What You Want to See]]''.<ref>{{cite album-notes |title=See What You Want to See |bandname=Radney Foster |year=1998 |format=CD insert |publisher=[[Arista Records]] |publisherid= 18833}}</ref> Rucker encouraged [[Atlantic Records]] to agree to a deal with [[Edwin McCain]], and made a guest appearance on McCain's debut album, [[Honor Among Thieves (album)|''Honor Among Thieves'']].<ref>Mukherjee, Tiarra; Murphy, Maggie (April 19, 1996), "Give a Hootie". ''Entertainment Weekly''. (323):10</ref>
==Solo career== In 2001, he made his solo [[R&B]] debut album, ''The Return of Mongo Slade'', for Atlantic Records. Because of contractual changes, it was never released by the label.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=darius-rucker-p227711/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Darius Rucker biography |accessdate=2008-05-07 |last=Wilson |first=MacKenzie |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> [[Hidden Beach Recordings]], an independent label, acquired the masters from Atlantic and released the album as ''[[Back to Then]]'' in July 2002.<ref name="allmusic"/> The album included work from the production team of [[Jill Scott]] and she made an appearance on the track "Hold On."<ref>Arnold, Chuck (August 12, 2002), "Back to Then (Music recording)". ''People''. '''58''' (7):45</ref>
Rucker appeared on a pop-star edition of the [[quiz show]] ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'' in July 2001.<ref>No byline (July 30, 2001), "Who Knows?". ''People''. '''56''' (5):54</ref> He also portrayed a [[singing cowboy]] in a television commercial for the fast food chain [[Burger King]], promoting their [[TenderCrisp]] Bacon Cheddar Ranch sandwich in 2005. In the commercial, he sang a jingle set to the tune of "[[Big Rock Candy Mountain]]."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://advertising.about.com/b/2005/03/07/yes-thats-hootie-crooning-for-burger-king.htm |title=Yes, that's Hootie crooning for Burger King |accessdate=2008-06-10 |last=Duncan |first=Apryl |date=2005-03-07 |work=[[About.com]]}}</ref>
===Country music=== ====Debut album (2008-2009)==== In early 2008, Rucker signed to [[Capitol Records]] Nashville as the beginning of a career in country music. His first solo single, "Don't Think I Don't Think About It" (which he co-wrote with [[Clay Mills]]) debuted at number 51 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts for the week of May 3, 2008. It is the first single from his second album, ''[[Learn to Live]]''. For this album, Rucker worked with [[Frank Rogers (record producer)|Frank Rogers]], a [[record producer]] who has also produced for [[Brad Paisley]] and [[Trace Adkins]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/article/hooties-darius-rucker-not-just-a-rocker-gone-country/|title=Hootie's Darius Rucker not just a rocker gone country|last=Taylor Jr.|first=Otis R.|date=19 September 2008|work=PopMatters|accessdate=22 November 2010}}</ref> Rucker also made his [[Grand Ole Opry]] debut in July 2008.<ref name="gac">{{cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,3034,GAC_26063_5908862_,00.html |title=Darius Rucker Basking in Country Success |accessdate=2008-08-24 |date=2008-07-23 |work=[[Great American Country|GAC]]}}</ref> "Don't Think I Don't Think About It" became the first top 20 hit for an African American on the country music charts since [[Charley Pride]]'s last Top 20 hit, which came in 1988.<ref name="the9513">{{cite web |url=http://www.the9513.com/rucker-proves-that-sometimes-the-best-marketing-is-no-marketing-at-all/ |title=Rucker Proves That Sometimes, The Best Marketing Is No Marketing At All |accessdate=2008-08-24 |last=C. |first=Matt |date=2008-08-13 |work=The 9513}}</ref> The single reached number one in September,<ref name="BB">Caulfield, Keith. [http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/charts/chart_alert/e3i6981db61c01d2a4dc258a2a3119dde7b "Metallica Holds At No. 1, Ne-Yo Arrives In Second "]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. September 24, 2008. Retrieved 23 November 2010.</ref> making Rucker the first solo, African-American artist to chart a number one country hit since Pride's "[[Night Games]]" in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ent/music/6310065.html|title=Darius Rucker thrilled to be living his dream|last=Guerra|first=Joey|date=13 March 2009|work=[[The Houston Chronicle]]|accessdate=22 November 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Darius Rucker, USAF.jpg|thumb|Rucker sings to a crowd during an Operation Pacific Greetings tour concert.]] ''Learn to Live'' was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) on February 6, 2009, and received a platinum certification on August 7, 2009.<ref name="RIAA">{{cite web|title=RIAA â Gold & Platinum|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Darius%20Rucker&format=ALBUM&go=Search&perPage=50|accessdate=2009-09-18}}</ref> The album's second single, "[[It Won't Be Like This for Long]]", spent three weeks at the top of the country charts in mid-2009. Its follow-up, "[[Alright (Darius Rucker song)|Alright]]", became Rucker's third straight number one hit, making him the first country music singer to have his or her first three singles reach number one since [[Wynonna Judd|Wynonna]] achieved that feat in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/column/chartbeat/chart-beat-darius-rucker-mariah-carey-brad-1004000604.story#/column/chartbeat/chart-beat-darius-rucker-mariah-carey-brad-1004000604.story|title=Chart Beat: Darius Rucker, Mariah Carey, Brad Paisley, Wilco |last=Trust|first=Gary|date=2009-08-05|work=Billboard|accessdate=2009-08-06}}</ref> The album's fourth single, "[[History in the Making]]" was released in September and peaked at number three on the country charts.<ref name="country peaks">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/artist/darius-rucker/chart-history/198757?f=357&g=Singles|title=Darius Rucker Album & Song Chart History â Country Songs|publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''|accessdate=September 14, 2010}}</ref> The singles from the album also crossed over to the [[Billboard Hot 100]], respectively peaking at numbers 35, 36, 30 and 61.<ref name="hot100 peaks">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/artist/darius-rucker/chart-history/198757?f=379&g=Singles|title=Darius Rucker Album & Song Chart History â Hot 100|publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''|accessdate=September 14, 2010}}</ref>
{{quote box|align=left|width=27%|quote="You see a lot of people doing a one-off, saying, 'This is my country record.' But this is a career I'm trying to build. The people that say that they don't get it, I'll let the music speak for itself. I plan to do a lot of country records."<ref>Tucker, Ken (May 10, 2008), "Genre-Bender". ''Billboard''. '''120''' (19):64</ref>|source=âRucker, ''Billboard'', 2008|style=padding:8px;}} Rucker's entry into the country world was met with some intrigue, largely because of his history as a rock musician and because he is African-American. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine said that "there's a sense of purpose that makes Rucker feel like a member of the country family, rather than calculating interloper."<ref>Price, Deborah Evans (June 28, 2008), "Don't Think I Don't Think About It". ''Billboard''. '''120''' (26):64</ref> Rucker made visits to various country stations around the US, explaining that he was aware that he was the "new kid on the block."<ref>Tucker, Ken (September 27, 2008), "New Kid On The Block". ''Billboard''. '''120''' (39):48</ref> Mike Culotta, the program director of the [[Tampa, Florida]] radio station [[WQYK-FM]] expected that Rucker would be "somebody who would have entitlement," but instead said that "Darius engaged everybody."<ref>No byline (September 23, 2008), "Hootie's Rucker tops country chart". ''USA Today''.</ref> When Rucker found that "Don't Think I Don't Think About It" went to number one, he cried.<ref>Greene, Andy (September 30, 2008), "Hootie and the Blowfish Singer Leads Country-Crossover Pack". ''Rolling Stone''. (1064)</ref> On November 11, 2009, Rucker won the [[Country Music Association]] New Artist of the Year award (formerly known as the Horizon Award), making him the first African American to do so since the award was introduced in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2009/11/12/2009-11-12_cmas_underdog_darius_rucker_of_hootie_and_the_blowfish_first_black_to_win_best_n.html|title=CMA's underdog: Darius Rucker of Hootie and the Blowfish, first black to win best new artist|last=Lapowsky|first=Issie|date=12 November 2009|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=21 November 2010}}</ref> Only one other African American has won at the CMAs: Charley Pride, who won entertainer of the year in 1971 and male vocalist in 1971 and 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/33825077/ns/today-entertainment|title=Darius Rucker shoots for country milestone|date=11 November 2009|work=Msnbc.com|accessdate=21 November 2010}}</ref>
====Second album (2010-present)==== Rucker released his second country album, titled ''[[Charleston, SC 1966]]'', on October 12, 2010. The title is inspired by [[Radney Foster]]'s solo debut album, ''[[Del Rio, TX 1959]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1643882/darius-rucker-schedules-new-album-charleston-sc-1966-for-oct-12.jhtml|title=Darius Rucker Schedules New Album, Charleston, SC 1966, for Oct. 12|date=16 July 2010|work=[[CMT]]|accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> Its first single was "[[Come Back Song]],"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/article/20100820/JUICE05/8200368/-1/NEWS13/Rucker-makes-easy-transition|title=Rucker makes easy transition|last=Lawler|first=Joe|date=20 August 2010|work=[[Des Moines Register]]|accessdate=22 August 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> which Rucker wrote with [[Chris Stapleton]] and [[Casey Beathard]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2010-06-08/darius-rucker-sings-a-groovy-come-back-song/|title=Darius Rucker Sings a Groovy "Come Back Song"|last=Shelburne|first=Craig|date=8 June 2010|work=CMT|accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> It was his fourth number one on the country charts as well as a number 37 hit on the Hot 100.<ref name="country peaks"/><ref name="hot100 peaks"/> The album's second single is "[[This (Darius Rucker song)|This]]", which was released to radio in November 2010 and also reached number one in the country charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aolradioblog.com/2010/11/08/darius-rucker-this/|title=Darius Rucker â "This"|last=Cheung|first=Nadine|date=8 November 2010|work=AOL Radio Blog|accessdate=21 November 2010}}</ref> Rucker wrote this song with Rogers and [[Kara DioGuardi]]. "[[I Got Nothin']]" is the album's third single.
==Personal life== Rucker is a [[Miami Dolphins]] fan, and has a tattoo of their logo.<ref>Rucker, Darius (March 23, 1995), "Raves". ''Rolling Stone''. (704):40</ref> He also likes the film ''[[Stir Crazy (film)|Stir Crazy]]'', which he has seen more than 100 times.<ref name=Kennedy/>
Rucker's mother died in November 1992 of a sudden heart attack.<ref name=Gray/><ref name=Kennedy/> His grief inspired two Hootie & the Blowfish songs: "I'm Goin' Home" and "Not Even the Trees."<ref name=farley/><ref name=Kennedy/> On April 21, 1995, Rucker became a father to a daughter, Carolyn Pearl Phillips. The girl's mother is Rucker's former girlfriend and the subject of "Let Her Cry", in which he flipped gender roles from those of reality.<ref name=Puterbaugh/> Daniella Roseâhis second daughter and his first with his wife Bethâwas born on May 16, 2001, in Charleston, South Carolina. Rucker and his wife Beth have a son, Jack who was born in 2005.<ref>Byrd, Veronica (June 4, 2001), "Passages". ''People''. '''55''' (22):107</ref> The Hootie song "Where Were You" is about Rucker's strained relationship with his father, and was only released in Europe, where Rucker thought that his father would be unlikely to hear it.<ref name=farley/> His country single "Alright" was inspired by his marriage to his wife, Beth.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|date=2009-09-07|title="Opposite" Song Delivers Smash|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=16|issue=30|pages=21|accessdate=2009-09-08}}</ref>
Rucker is close friends with golfer [[Tiger Woods]], whom he met in a bar when Woods was 18. Rucker sang at the golfer's wedding with Hootie & the Blowfish, and at [[Earl Woods|his father's]] funeral.<ref>Dyball, Rennie (September 8, 2008), "Catching Up With... Darius Rucker". ''People''. '''70''' (10):56</ref>
